By PETER HARNIK
Dr. David Butler, in a talk before the Young Democrats last
Tuesday, predicted that "the
Vietnam war is likely to go on
for years and years."
Dr. Butler, a first year professor in the Political Science department,lectured on "The Elections: Prelude to What?" His
analysis included the situation
before, during and immediately
following the October elections
in Vietnam, and then speculated
on their probable effects.
Withdrawal of Ky
Butler described the surprise
withdrawal of Ky from the presidential race in South Vietnam.
Ky, the then current head of the
ruling military junta, had, to that
time, been the most durable of
the succession of generals who
have ruled Vietnam sirice the
overthrow of Ngo Dinh Diem.
Through various developments, Thieu, the underdog,
managed to discredit the Ky
government and force Ky's resignation. "Ky was surprised
when this was accepted, but he
finally obtained the Vice-Presidential slot." Butler said.
Military Character
Butler asserted that the election confirmed the military character of the situation, but that
the present policies of the new
government have been effected
without widespread dissent from
civilian leaders.
Viewing the future, Butler
stated that "We'll be lucky if we
get back to the Diem situation."
Butler felt that the only sem-

••••••

blance of centralization in Vietnam, existed under the Diem
regime.
Criticizes U.S.
He criticized the United States
for only half-heartedly introducing American representative procedures into the South Vietnamese political scene."We've tried
to transfer power from the military to various ghostly interest
groups," he said, "but the election came too soon and exposed
these groups - - the religious leaders, and some secret organizations headed by peace candidates, especially - - as mere
"phantoms."
Buying Corruption
Dr. Butler stated that we
should have postponed the elections, formed a coalition, and,
using covert financing, strengthened the interest groups so that
they would have provided a viable alternative to the military.
"Now we might have to involve large segments of the elite
in paper-shuffling,like the French
did, to preserve at least a facade
of coexistent amity." He charged
that the U.S. is managing to buy
off corruption by exporting luxury commodities into Viet Nam.
Butler compared it to "picking
the lice off corruption while we
keep down inflation." He added
that we have already poured so
much money into the country,
"that we could have bought it at
$500 an acre."
What Goals?
Butler predicted that certain
old problems were likely to resurface. including a conflict with
the U.S. over the actual war
goals. "We wanted the power to
shift - - and it didn't. The elections failed to break some sort of
psychological iron curtain, and
open up new channels of understanding."

PROTESTORS, ARISE!
To the Editors:
It's foolish to believe that the
war in Vietnam will go away if
LBJ is re-elected, if McCarthy is
the next President, if Rusk and
Westmoreland go, etc., etc. The
notion that our leaders are the
Supreme and Enlightened Authority with complete control over
our individual and collective destinies has been drummed into
our heads from grade school onwards. We feel that we are insignificant, that the ordinary citizen is politically impotent.
The truth of the matter is
that we ourselves have the power
to end the war in Vietnam and to
stop the genocide our government is committing in our name.
We can end the war by choosing
not to fight it! I made that
choice last Monday at the Customs House when I turned in my
draft card to General Hershey.
Many other men throughout this
country have made that choice.
If you support our draft resistance and continue to stick with
us, then we ourselves will very
quickly bring the tragedy in
Vietnam to a close.
Harold Kasinsky, Ph.D.

Good Health
It is comforting to know that dormitory students here are receiving far healthier food than students in College Park. After all,
we received a mere ten infractions, compared to Maryland's 80 or
more. But then, we are considered a better university.
We wonder how many peeling walls and dirty hairs are found
at Harvard and Yale, the perennial causes of our academic guilt
feelings. They are really good universitites, and so, our tentative
hypothesis goes, they must have one, maybe two health problems.
In fact, one wonders what the whole fuss about health infractions is all about anyway. Some of the best food in France comes
out of cuisines unfit for the lowliest Calvert St. roach.

Graffiti Malaise
The writing of fine, subtle graffiti is an art. Just as few have
the ability to write a good short story or a poem, or even conceive of a metaphor, few have the ability to place a successful
obscenity on a bathroom wall. Hopkins students, it seems, have
even less ability than most Baltimoreans, who encrust their scribblings on less academic shrines.
It is embarrassing to see such sophomoric attempts at exhibitionistic self-eroticism in a university prized for its intelligent students. Any Green mount bar hop, from a quick perusal of Levering and Library toilets, would think this institution to be Charenton rather than Hopkins. No subtlety, no wit, no humor, no

Rudolf Serkin is an old man.
He walked onstage and we applauded our respect. When he
touched the piano, he grasped
and held us. He wept, shouted,
ranted and laughed. Every statement was a combination of mathmatical elegance and triumphant
emotion. Each sforzando threw
him from the piano in an outburst of ecstatic violence. The
lyric movements sang. Rudolf
Serkin proved himself the master.
Schubert's Sonata in A major,
(Op. Posthumous) was the first
piece on the program. The majesty of the opening led into a
submerged violence. The elegant,
wry andantino was the perfect introduction for the lively scherzo.
The rondo was a long, songmore like movement. Serkin
swayed and sang in celebration
for the nobility of the finale.
However, his actions were not
the showmanship of the stageconscious pseudo-virtuoso. They
were those of a man with an unfailing instinct for the larger sense
of the piece.
Beethoven's "Le Adieux"Sonata opened the second half of
the concert. The cold, pure notes
of the adagio were arranged and

given to produce a warm beauty.
Serkin retold Beethoven poetically and powerfully. He held and
loved each note of the andante
before releasing it to the audience. Both Serkin and the audience were rewarded for hi', care.
The vivacissimamente was a
display of joyful virtuosity. Beethoven in Serkin gave a triumphant, free, almost insane laughter.,
Serkin in Beethoven was victorious. The piece ended in a doubleshift from violent power to a
mood of pensive strength into a
last release of joyful energy.
The last composition on the
program was Variations and
Fugue on a Theme of Handel,
Op. 24 by Brahms. Serkin masterfully enunciated a set of heavenly, yet dynamic variations and
finished with a rousing fugue.
Rudolf Serkin's performance
has more graceful, gentle, simplicity and rugged energy. However,
above all, there was an overriding
perfect logic. This naturalness
was a result of the fact that Serkin does not merely play notes.
He plays sensation. The limitations are shaken off and Serkin
wins the battle by showing the
sustratum of elation inherent in
struggle.

the pleasures of live; and Shrdlu
and Zero, who at first appeared
so very different, are cast from
the same mold,a mold which we,
by implication, are also cast from.

Dr. David Butler, in a talk before the Young Democrats last
Tuesday, predicted that "the
Vietnam war is likely to go on
for years and years."
Dr. Butler, a first year professor in the Political Science department,lectured on "The Elections: Prelude to What?" His
analysis included the situation
before, during and immediately
following the October elections
in Vietnam, and then speculated
on their probable effects.
Withdrawal of Ky
Butler described the surprise
withdrawal of Ky from the presidential race in South Vietnam.
Ky, the then current head of the
ruling military junta, had, to that
time, been the most durable of
the succession of generals who
have ruled Vietnam sirice the
overthrow of Ngo Dinh Diem.
Through various developments, Thieu, the underdog,
managed to discredit the Ky
government and force Ky's resignation. "Ky was surprised
when this was accepted, but he
finally obtained the Vice-Presidential slot." Butler said.
Military Character
Butler asserted that the election confirmed the military character of the situation, but that
the present policies of the new
government have been effected
without widespread dissent from
civilian leaders.
Viewing the future, Butler
stated that "We'll be lucky if we
get back to the Diem situation."
Butler felt that the only sem-

blance of centralization in Vietnam, existed under the Diem
regime.
Criticizes U.S.
He criticized the United States
for only half-heartedly introducing American representative procedures into the South Vietnamese political scene."We've tried
to transfer power from the military to various ghostly interest
groups," he said, "but the election came too soon and exposed
these groups - - the religious leaders, and some secret organizations headed by peace candidates, especially - - as mere
"phantoms."
Buying Corruption
Dr. Butler stated that we
should have postponed the elections, formed a coalition, and,
using covert financing, strengthened the interest groups so that
they would have provided a viable alternative to the military.
"Now we might have to involve large segments of the elite
in paper-shuffling,like the French
did, to preserve at least a facade
of coexistent amity." He charged
that the U.S. is managing to buy
off corruption by exporting luxury commodities into Viet Nam.
Butler compared it to "picking
the lice off corruption while we
keep down inflation." He added
that we have already poured so
much money into the country,
"that we could have bought it at
$500 an acre."
What Goals?
Butler predicted that certain
old problems were likely to resurface. including a conflict with
the U.S. over the actual war
goals. "We wanted the power to
shift - - and it didn't. The elections failed to break some sort of
psychological iron curtain, and
open up new channels of understanding."
